2:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"leading-none font-semibold flex items-center gap-2","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-2xl","children":"Vos"}],"vs",["$","span",null,{"className":"text-2xl text-muted-foreground","children":"Tú"}]]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-4","children":[["$","p",null,{"children":"Forget everything you learned about \"tú.\" In Argentina, everyone uses \"vos\" for informal situations. The conjugations are different, and yes, you need to learn them."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-muted p-4 rounded-lg space-y-2","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"Standard Spanish → Argentine Spanish"}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Tú eres"}]," → ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Vos sos"}]," (You are)"]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Tú tienes"}]," → ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Vos tenés"}]," (You have)"]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Tú hablas"}]," → ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Vos hablás"}]," (You speak)"]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Tú vienes"}]," → ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Vos venís"}]," (You come)"]}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"The stress moves to the last syllable. It's actually more regular than standard Spanish, but it feels wrong at first."}]]}]]}]
3:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"leading-none font-semibold","children":"The \"Sh\" Sound"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-4","children":[["$","p",null,{"children":"The most distinctive feature of Argentine Spanish: \"ll\" and \"y\" are pronounced like \"sh\" in \"sheep.\" This is called \"yeísmo rehilado.\""}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-muted p-4 rounded-lg space-y-2","children":[["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Calle"}]," (street) → ",["$","em",null,{"children":"CA-sheh"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Lluvia"}]," (rain) → ",["$","em",null,{"children":"SHU-via"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Yo"}]," (I) → ",["$","em",null,{"children":"SHO"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Playa"}]," (beach) → ",["$","em",null,{"children":"PLA-sha"}]]}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"In other Spanish-speaking countries, these sound like \"y\" in \"yes.\" In Argentina, it's all \"sh.\" You'll get weird looks if you don't do it."}]]}]]}]
4:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"leading-none font-semibold","children":"Porteño Accent Challenges"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-4","children":[["$","p",null,{"children":"Porteños (Buenos Aires locals) speak fast, drop syllables, and have their own rhythm. Here's what makes it hard:"}],["$","ul",null,{"className":"space-y-2 text-sm","children":[["$","li",null,{"children":["• ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Speed:"}]," They talk fast. Really fast."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":["• ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Italian influence:"}]," The intonation sounds almost Italian"]}],["$","li",null,{"children":["• ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"Syllable dropping:"}]," \"Para\" becomes \"pa,\" \"para el\" becomes \"pal\""]}],["$","li",null,{"children":["• ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"\"Que\" becomes \"ke\":"}]," But that's standard Spanish"]}],["$","li",null,{"children":["• ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"S at the end of words:"}]," Often barely pronounced or dropped"]}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"Don't expect to understand group conversations for at least 3-6 months. One-on-one is much easier."}]]}]]}]

Can get crowded and tourist-heavy, but it's a good starting point. Arrive early to get a seat."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs mt-2 italic text-primary","children":"Don't just talk to other foreigners. Force yourself to find Argentines."}]]}],["$","div","Mundo Lingo",{"className":"bg-muted p-4 rounded-lg","children":[["$","h4",null,{"className":"font-semibold mb-2","children":"Mundo Lingo"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"text-sm space-y-1 text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Where:"}]," ","Changes weekly"]}],["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"When:"}]," ","Wednesdays, 8 PM"]}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm mt-2","children":"More structured than Mate Club. 3b:["$","div",null,{"className":"grid md:grid-cols-2 gap-6 mt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"leading-none font-semibold","children":"Pronunciation Pitfalls"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"space-y-3","children":[["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"Rolling your R's"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"The double R (rr) and R at the start of words are rolled. Practice with \"perro\" (dog) vs \"pero\" (but). If you can't roll your R's, don't stress - you'll be understood."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"The J sound"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"Spanish J is like a strong H. \"Jorge\" sounds like \"HOR-heh,\" not like English J."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"V vs B"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"In Spanish, V and B sound almost the same - like a soft B. \"Vino\" and \"bino\" sound identical."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"H is always silent"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"\"Hola\" is pronounced \"OH-la,\" not \"HO-la.\""}]]}]]}]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"leading-none font-semibold","children":"Cultural Context Mistakes"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"space-y-3","children":[["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"\"Te amo\" vs \"Te quiero\""}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"\"Te amo\" is serious - reserved for romantic love or family. \"Te quiero\" is for friends, casual relationships, and early dating. Don't scare people off with \"te amo\" too soon."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"Personal space"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentines kiss on the cheek (one cheek) when greeting. Even men greet women this way. Don't go for the handshake - it's cold."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"\"No\" doesn't always mean no"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentines are indirect. \"Maybe\" often means no. \"We'll see\" means probably not. Learn to read between the lines."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"font-medium","children":"Time is flexible"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"If someone says \"I'll be there at 9,\" they mean 9:30 or 10. Don't take it personally. It's just how things work here."}]]}]]}]}]]}]]}]
